reviewing this this is the IFI explore
card right there it's a hundred thirty
dollar memory card it works like a
regular memory card for your camera
except for two things first of all every
time you enter your home Wi-Fi wireless
network it automatically transmits all
the pictures on the card back to your
computer nice and online to photo
sharing websites like Flickr but the
really amazing trick is geo tagging this
card invisibly stamps each photo with
the latitude and longitude of the spot
where it was taken so later on the web
or on your computer you can see where
exactly you are standing when you took
the shot now this is very cool and all
but might get it cool that's very funny
but my my question is how is it doing
that it's not GPS you couldn't possibly
fit GPS into something this small turns
out it's using a new sort of fake GPS
from a company called skyhook for five
years these guys have been sent
500 full-time drivers through every
street in America detecting people's
Wi-Fi hotspots all those 70 million
wireless base stations in homes and
coffee shops and offices the idea is
that they're building up a massive
database that associates eats base
stations unique network address with its
physical location now suppose that you
have a Wi-Fi gadget that has the skyhook
software in it like this memory card by
detecting the overlapping signals from
all of these base stations around it it
can get a fix on your location accurate
to within about a hundred feet it's just
like GPS but without the gps actually
gps and skyhook work very well together
because gps doesn't work indoors and
skyhook does yet gps works great when
you're far from civilization like when
you're camping or sailing or hiking and
that's exactly where a skyhook falls
down because there aren't many Wi-Fi
base stations outside of the metro areas
so so far skyhook covers about seventy
percent of the populated areas and the
united states and maybe that is why the
new iphone coming out in a couple of
weeks has both built in gps and skyhook
